journal-title-group.journal-title: The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology and Metabolism

title-group.article-title: A Narrative Review of Placental Contribution to Adverse Pregnancy Outcomes in Women With Polycystic Ovary Syndrome

article-meta.aff: 1 Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Michigan
2 Department of Pediatrics, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Michigan

author-notes.corresp: Correspondence and Reprint Requests: Vasantha Padmanabhan, PhD, Department of Pediatrics, University of Michigan, 7510 MSRB 1, 1500 West Medical Center Drive, Ann Arbor, Michigan 48109. E-mail: vasantha@umich.edu.

sec.title: Context
sec.p: Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is the most common endocrinopathy of reproductive-aged women. In pregnancy, women with PCOS experience increased risk of miscarriage, gestational diabetes, preeclampsia, and extremes of fetal birth weight, and their offspring are predisposed to reproductive and cardiometabolic dysfunction in adulthood. Pregnancy complications, adverse fetal outcomes, and developmental programming of long-term health risks are known to have placental origins. These findings highlight the plausibility of placental compromise in pregnancies of women with PCOS.

sec.title: Evidence Synthesis
sec.p: A comprehensive PubMed search was performed using terms “polycystic ovary syndrome,” “placenta,” “developmental programming,” “hyperandrogenism,” “androgen excess,” “insulin resistance,” “hyperinsulinemia,” “pregnancy,” and “pregnancy complications” in both human and animal experimental models.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: There is limited human placental research specific to pregnancy of women with PCOS. Gestational androgen excess and insulin resistance are two clinical hallmarks of PCOS that may contribute to placental dysfunction and underlie the higher rates of maternal–fetal complications observed in pregnancies of women with PCOS. Additional research is needed to prevent adverse maternal and developmental outcomes in women with PCOS and their offspring.

abstract.p: In this review, we summarize current knowledge of placental dysfunction in human and animal models of PCOS and propose future directions for placental research in the population with PCOS.
